entry.title: From Basics to Confidence: Testing SAP BTP iFlows with Postman
entry.content:
After building my first iFlow in SAP BTP Integration Suite, I was excited to test it — but I wasn’t sure where to start. That’s when I discovered Postman, a simple tool for testing HTTP requests. In this blog, I’ll walk you through how I used Postman to test my iFlow, and what I learned along the way. 

🔄What I Built 

I created a Mail Adapter iFlow: 

  • Trigger: HTTP POST request 
  • Step: Content Modifier (formatting) 
  • Output: Mail Adapter (send a notification email) 

The goal? Trigger the iFlow from Postman and see the email arrive. 

 

🔧Step 1: Set Up the iFlow 

  • Navigate to Design Workspace

    • Go to Integration Suite → Design → Integration & APIs

  • Create a New Package

    • Click Create Package
    • Enter Name: Mail_Testing

  • Add an Artifact to the Package

    • Open the Mail_Testing package
    • Click Create → Integration Flow

  • Configure the iFlow

    • Name: Mail_Simple
    • Click Add and Open in Editor

Design and Deploy the Mail iFlow:

  1. Edit the iFlow

    • Click Edit in the iFlow editor

  2. Modify the Start Event

    • Delete the default Sender
    • Add a Timer from the Event section
    • Delete the Start element

  3. Configure the Timer

    • Open the Timer Scheduler
    • Keep the configuration basic (default settings)

  4. Add a Content Modifier

    • Drag and drop a Content Modifier into the flow
    • Configure Message Body:
      • Type: Constant
      • Value:
        Hi All,
This is for sample testing mail.
Thanks & Regards,

  5. Connect to Mail Receiver

    • Connect the End of the flow to a Receiver
    • Select Mail Adapter as the receiver type

  6. Configure Mail Adapter Connection

    • Address: smtp.gmail.com:587
    • Protection: Optional
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Authorization Code
    • Credential Name: IS_GMAIL

  7. Set Mail Processing Details

    • From: Sender's mail
    • To: Receiver's mail
    • Subject: Testing

  8. Save and Deploy

    • Click Save
    • Click Deploy to activate the iFlow

Step 2: Configure OAuth2 Authorization Code in SAP BTP Integration Suite

  1. Navigate to Security Material

    • Go to Integration Suite → Monitor → Integration & APIs → Security Material

  2. Create New OAuth2 Authorization Code

    • Click Create
    • Select OAuth2 Authorization Code as the type.

  3. Fill in Configuration Details

    • Name: IS_GMAIL
    • Description: Gmail configuration
    • Provider: Generic
    • Authorization URL: <authuri>?access_type=offline&prompt=consent
    • Token URL: <authuri>/token
    • Client ID: <clientid>
    • Client Secret: <clientsecret>
    • Send As: Basic Authentication Header
    • Username: "sender's mail id"
    • Scope: https://mail.google.com/

 

🔗Step 3: Get the Endpoint URL 
After deployment: 

  • Go to Monitor → Manage Integration Content 
    Under Monitor- Integrations and API, added a security material for OAuth Authorization.
  • Find your iFlow and copy the endpoint URL 

🧪 Step 4: Test in Postman 
In Postman: 

  • Method: POST 
  • URL: Paste your endpoint 
  • Authorization: Basic Auth 
  • Use your Integration Suite credentials 
  • Headers: 
  • Content-Type: application/json 
  • Body (raw, JSON): 

json 

{ 

  "name": "Pranjali", 

  "email": "abc@example.com", 

  "message": "Test from Postman!" 

} 

Click Send. 

📈Step 5: Check the Results 

In SAP BTP: 

  • Go to Monitor → Monitor Message Processing 
  • Look for your iFlow execution 
  • Open the message to see: 
  • Payload trace 
  • Adapter logs 
  • Success or error details 

  

🧠 Tips & Common Errors that you phase while deploying the iflow:

  

Error 

Cause 

Fix 

401 

Unauthorized Wrong credentials or missing role 

Ensure ESBMessaging.send role is assigned 

404 

Not Found Incorrect endpoint 

Verify path /triggerEmail matches exactly 

Empty or broken payload 

Incorrect headers 

Add Content-Type: application/json 

Mail not received 

Mail adapter config issue 

Double-check SMTP host, port, and credentials 

Flow doesn’t appear in monitor 

Wrong trigger format 

 Ensure JSON body is well-formed and matches iFlow expectations 

  

✅Final Thoughts 

Testing your iFlows doesn’t need to be hard. Postman made it quick and easy for me to validate my flow and debug it. If you’re just getting started with SAP BTP Integration Suite, I highly recommend trying this out with a simple HTTP-to-Mail flow.

entry.title: How to Get Started with SAP S/4HANA and Amazon Seller Central Integration
entry.content:
Integrating Amazon Seller Central with SAP S/4HANA can sound like a complex project. But if you’re an Amazon merchant already using SAP, connecting the two can significantly boost your operations. In this article, we’ll cover everything you need to know before jumping in—from Amazon’s merchant models and APIs to setting up your SAP system and choosing the right integration method.

Read here when I started my journey and asked this same community about storing ASIN numbers within SAP.

Note: This article is part of a series. Stay tuned for upcoming posts on Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM), Fulfilled by Amazon (FBA), and best practices for SAP-Amazon integrations.

Amazon Merchant Models: What You Need to Know

Amazon offers several models for merchants to sign up, and understanding which commercial agreement you fall under is crucial for exploring the available solutions.

  • Vendor Central – This is an invite-only model where Amazon acts as a B2B partner by issuing a purchase order. The merchant supplies the goods to Amazon at an agreed-upon price and invoices Amazon accordingly. Amazon then takes care of selling the products, generating a profit from the sale. In this arrangement, the merchant has no control over the listed price or the final customer transaction.

As this model is a special case and relatively easy to integrate, we will cover it in more detail in a separate blog post.

  • Seller Central – In this model, the seller lists products on Amazon and is responsible for setting the price, handling customer orders, and fulfilling them. There are two sub-models for Seller Central:
  • Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM) – The seller stores the products in their own warehouse. When Amazon orders are placed, the seller’s logistics team picks and ships the products directly to the customer.
  • Fulfilled by Amazon (FBA) – Amazon stores the products on behalf of the merchant, distributing the inventory across its fulfillment centers based on demand. In this case, the merchant is only responsible for sending inventory to Amazon’s warehouses and restocking as necessary.

In both sub-models, Amazon pays the merchant every two weeks based on the sales of goods, minus Amazon’s fees and charges. We’ll discuss these fees in more detail shortly.

Understanding Amazon’s Fees vs Charges

Fees are the portion of the sales transaction that Amazon takes, such as the commission. This commission is deducted directly from the merchant’s payout after a sale. It represents Amazon’s share for providing the platform and services to facilitate the transaction. Merchants need to account for these fees when calculating their profits.

Charges, on the other hand, are costs that the customer pays. These may include shipping fees, taxes, or other additional costs associated with the purchase. Unlike fees, which are deducted from the merchant’s payout, charges are directly paid by the customer at checkout. The merchant does not bear the responsibility for these costs. Instead, they are part of the overall price the customer agrees to pay.

It must be noted that these Fees / Charges need to be recorded when Orders flow into SAP. For this reason, each of the relevant Fees and Charge need to be mapped to condition type.

There are a lot of fees and charges associated with Amazon and may be all of them do not apply to your case. You can get an estimate of Amazon fees and charges out here.

As shown above it is good the store all the Amazon fees and charges in a custom table to be able to further solutionize the integration.

Master Data Setup in SAP for Amazon Integration

To be able to set Amazon process within Amazon, you need to ensure that founding pillars are in place. Here are the details.

  • Plant / Customer – In both FBM and FBA Scenarios, you would need to track inventory as well as accept orders from Amazon. You would need to create Amazon as a customer as well as plant within SAP system

     

     

  • Material – All the material relevant for Amazon business must have an ASIN (Amazon Standard Identification Number). These are required be maintained and link with material master relevant for Amazon business. The best way to do the same is to maintain these are customer material info records with respect to customer created in above step.

Extending your materials for the Amazon-specific plant ensures SAP recognizes the stock location used for Amazon orders.

Technical Structure: Understanding Amazon SP-API

The next step is to understand the Amazon API structure. I have worked with various integrations and can say that using these APIs requires moderate to advanced knowledge. This is because there are interdependencies in how some methods work. Additionally, some methods have asynchronous behaviors.

Understanding these details is important for successful integration. Details for these APIs can be found out here. One important step before starting the integration is obtaining a developer key. You can find the developer registration link here.

However, the process of gaining developer access can be quite lengthy, with wait times sometimes reaching up to 6 months. To learn more about ***REMOVED BY MODERATION*** It must also be noted that Developer access requires an annual audit and approval process from Amazon.

It must also be noted that Developer access requires an annual audit and approval process from Amazon.

In my company, we typically spend 2 man-month to pass Amazon’s review every year.

Spoiler
If you have tight timelines or lack the resources to manage and maintain an Amazon integration, consider exploring a ready-made solution between Amazon and SAP. This can be a more efficient and practical option.

Amazon SP-API Categories

Amazon offers several categories of APIs. While there are many available, I have outlined the purpose of the key ones below.

Serial NoCategoryPurpose

1 Catalog List and update catalog and merchandise on Amazon.
2 Pricing Fees and Promotions

Modify pricing and run promotions, as well as estimate product fees.
3 Inventory Management

Retrieve product listings and inventory information.
4

Order Fulfillment

Update fulfillment-related information.
5

Order Management

Synchronize Amazon order status changes.
6

Fulfillment by Amazon (FBA)

APIs for FBA-related scenarios.
7

Returns Management

Retrieve information on customer-initiated returns.
8

Finance and Settlement

Reconcile Amazon payments with sales transactions.
9

Tax Reporting

Retrieve tax collected and remit accordingly.

Amazon Access and Refresh token

To call Amazon REST APIs, you need an access token. Access tokens usually expire after 60 minutes. Once expired, you will need to get a new one. To get a new access token, you need a refresh token. The refresh token allows you to generate a new access token. You can learn more about this process in the video below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7-WzaFXvQeg

Example to retrieve Amazon Orders using API

This example below from Amazon shows how to

  1. Invoke Orders API from Amazon passing the required tokens
  2. Fetch the Order details
  3. Get shipping addresses

https://developer-docs.amazon.com/sp-api/recipes?ld=NSGoogle

 

Integration Options for SAP and Amazon

There are four main integration approaches between SAP and Amazon Seller Central, each catering to different business sizes and technical capabilities.

The first is Custom integration via SAP CPI, which offers the highest flexibility and control. This is ideal for organizations with strong internal IT teams who can manage the custom mappings and maintain the integration logic. However, it requires a developer account with Amazon, deep API understanding, and ongoing maintenance.

The second option is EDI-based integration, typically used by enterprises already exchanging documents with trading partners. Amazon can be added as another EDI partner, but this method is asynchronous and lacks the real-time granularity often needed for eCommerce. It's simpler in setup but can introduce delays in order sync and inventory updates.

The more modern alternatives include OMS platforms or iPaaS tools. These do not require Amazon Developer ID or developing custom code from scratch. They come with prebuilt connectors and templates that significantly shorten the go-live timeline.

iPaaS is especially attractive for mid-sized businesses looking for real-time integration without heavy IT investment. These tools offer a balanced approach by reducing manual work, improving compliance, and ensuring long-term scalability.

Tip: Prebuilt iPaaS solutions reduce go-live time and long-term maintenance while ensuring compliance.

Planning for Integration Success

Here are key touch-points to consider.

  •  Inventory Sync: Control how much stock you expose to Amazon. Use a dedicated storage location or plant. The available to promise quantity in SAP must be synced with Amazon.

  • Price and Promotions: Mirror your SAP pricing logic on Amazon—including discounts or holiday sales.

 

In this case the price for ASIN B07122C9VC should be set as $8.00. If a Holiday sale is set up in SAP and it creates a discount of 20%, it should set the price to $6.40 automatically on Amazon.

  • Order Sync: Amazon becomes Sold to, Bill To and Payer. Shipping address will depend on FBA / FBM scenario which we will cover in the coming tutorial. 
  • Tracking & Fulfillment: Automatically update Amazon with shipment tracking from SAP.
  • Returns: Credit Memo Requests in SAP reflect Amazon-initiated returns.

Why Getting an Amazon Developer ID Is Tough

Be ready for:

  • Application queues (3–6 months)
  • Annual review cycles
  • Security and PII compliance (non-negotiable)

Amazon enforces strict compliance standards and has recently started working with third-party audit firms to conduct detailed due diligence on all partners using a Developer ID. It’s not that Amazon discourages integrations.

In fact, they support developer-driven innovation, but ensuring regulatory and data privacy compliance remains a top priority.

Final Thoughts

Integrating SAP S/4HANA with Amazon Seller Central is not just about API calls—it’s about aligning two ecosystems. With the right master data, process mapping, and secure API setup, the integration can be seamless and scalable. In the next article, we’ll explore how to configure SAP S/4HANA for Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM) scenarios.

Additional Resource - How to Grow your Amazon Business

20 Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

Here are some frequently asked question on SAP and Amazon integration.

Here are some frequently asked question on SAP and Amazon integration.

  1. What is SAP Amazon Seller Central integration?
    It's the process of connecting your Amazon Seller Central account with SAP so that orders, inventory, and payments can flow automatically between both systems.
  2. How do I connect Amazon Seller Central to SAP S/4HANA?
    You can use Amazon APIs and integrate them into SAP via custom development, middleware like SAP CPI, or use ready-to-use connectors available in iPaaS platforms.
  3. What is Amazon SP-API?
    SP-API (Selling Partner API) is Amazon's new set of REST APIs that let you manage orders, inventory, pricing, reports, and more.
  4. What are the steps to get an Amazon Developer ID?
    You have to apply on Amazon’s developer portal, explain your use case, undergo an approval process, and pass a compliance review. It can take 3–6 months.
  5. What’s the difference between FBM and FBA?
    FBM (Fulfilled by Merchant) means you handle storage and shipping. FBA (Fulfilled by Amazon) means Amazon stores and ships your products.
  6. How are Amazon fees handled in SAP?
    They are mapped to manual condition types in the SAP Sales Order so your financials stay accurate.
  7. Can I use SAP CPI to integrate with Amazon?
    Yes, but you'll need to build custom mappings and have Amazon API expertise.
  8. Is there an iPaaS connector available for Amazon SAP integration?
    Yes, platforms like APPSeCONNECT and others offer prebuilt connectors that work out of the box.
  9. How is inventory synced between Amazon and SAP?
    SAP's Available-to-Promise (ATP) quantity is pushed to Amazon using their Inventory API.
  10. How is ASIN mapped to SAP material master?
    You maintain ASIN numbers in Customer Material Info Records tied to Amazon as a customer.
  11. What’s the process for API authentication with Amazon?
    You use access tokens that expire every hour. When they expire, you generate a new one using a refresh token.
  12. Why does Amazon require annual audits for Developer IDs?
    To ensure data privacy and security compliance, especially with customer (PII) data.
  13. What happens if I exceed Amazon API limits?
    You’ll hit throttling errors and your API calls will be delayed or blocked. It’s important to batch and schedule wisely.
  14. Can I integrate Amazon with SAP without custom development?
    Yes, by using iPaaS or OMS platforms that come with prebuilt SAP and Amazon connectors.
  15. Is EDI a good option for Amazon integration?
    It can work, but it’s not real-time and may miss some detailed data. It’s better suited for simpler or legacy setups.
  16. How do I map Amazon fees to condition types in SAP?
    Create manual condition types for each fee category and link them in the Sales Order during order sync.
  17. What are some common issues in SAP-Amazon integration?
    Token expiries, throttling, PII access, and missing master data (like ASINs or plants) can cause trouble.
  18. How do I reconcile Amazon payments in SAP?
    You can fetch reports via API and map them to your receivables, netting out fees and returns automatically.
  19. What are the best tools for order sync?
    SAP CPI (for custom setups), iPaaS (like APPSeCONNECT), or OMS platforms are great options depending on your needs.
  20. How long does it take to fully integrate SAP with Amazon?
    It can take anywhere from 4 to 20 weeks depending on whether you're building custom or using a prebuilt solution.
  21. Does the solution work for ECC and Amazon too?
    Yes. The same solution can work for SAP ECC too.

Stay tuned for: How to Configure SAP S/4HANA with Amazon Seller Central for Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM)

entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): SAP S/4HANA Business Partner Replication using DRF Customizing
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog builds on our earlier post on SAP MDI Architecture and Deployment. Here, we explore end-to-end configuration for replicating Business Partner data from an SAP S/4HANA system to SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) using SOAP-based communication and DRF (Data Replication Framework).

Prerequisites

Ensure the following are in place:

  • SAP MDI service instance and service key created in SAP BTP Cockpit
  • DRF enabled in the S/4HANA system
  • Role-based access to SOAMANAGER
  • Active connectivity between SAP BTP and On-Premises via SAP Cloud Connector

DRF Configuration

  • In DRFIMG, create a Business System with BO Type and Communication System "Replication via Services" for the object "986" for Business Partner including Relationships.
  • Ensure the Business System ID matches the one used in the MDO configuration to avoid integration errors.
  • Assign Outbound Implementation "986_3 Outbound Implementation for BP/REL via Services", Assign Target System and Outbound Parameters under "Define Replication Models".
  • Repeat steps above for Key Mapping as 1376 if the integration scenario requires key mapping replication.

 WSDL Setup via SOAMANAGER

Download WSDLs

  • Download 6 WSDLs as per SAP Note 2987243

Customize and Upload
  • Now we have the below 6 WSDL Files:
    BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
    BusinessPartnerRelationshipSUITEBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    BusinessPartnerRelationshipSUITEBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
    KeyMappingBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    KeyMappingBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
  • Add the following elements at the end of each of the WSDL Files before the </wsdl:definitions> tag.
  • It is important to note that the below XML element contains a sample SAP Master Data Integration Endpoint.
    <wsdl:service name="...">
    <wsdl:port name="..." binding="...">
    <soap:address location="https://<uri>:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=<identity_zone>" />
    </wsdl:port>
    </wsdl:service>
  • You need to replace this with your Master Data Integration details for all of them.
    The SAP Master Data Integration Endpoint is of the following pattern:<uri>:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=<identity_zone>
    In the above pattern:
    URI is equal to the value of attribute “uri” in your Master Data Integration instance’s service key
    identity_zone is equal to the value of attribute “identity zone” in your Master Data Integration instance’s service key
    Example for 1 WSDL- https://one.mds.cfapps.sap.hana.ondemand.com:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=mdibpconsumer1
  • Upload all 6 WSDLs in SOA Management

Publish WSDLs to Services Registry

  • Use Services Registry → Publication of External WSDL
  • Assign appropriate internal names, bindings, and physical systems
  • Reuse the physical system object across all WSDLs after first creation

MDI System Access Profile

  • Go to Technical Administration → Profiles
  • Create a new profile with:
    Auth: User ID/Password
    Transport: Secured communication
  • Link this profile to the provider system using the same Business System ID as DRF

Logon Data Management

  • Go to Service Administration → Logon Data Management
  • Create credentials using:
    clientId as username
    clientSecret as password from the MDI service key

Local Integration Scenario Configuration

  • Go to Local Integration Scenario Configuration
  • Add these service groups:
    MDG_BS_SUPPLIERREPLICATEREQ
    MDG_BS_SUPPLIERREPLICATECONF
    KEY_MAP_REPLICATE_REQ
    KEY_MAP_REPLICATE_CONF

  • Assign IBC Reference to each from the MDI system
  • Link all service groups to the created Logon Data

Activate Logical Ports

  • Go to Service Administration → Pending Tasks
  • Process all pending tasks
  • Validate port creation via Web Service Configuration

SOAP Endpoint Setup for MDI

  • Go to Web Service Configuration
  • For each of the 6 service definitions (e.g. BUSINESSPARTNERSUITEBULKREPLIC), create a service binding
  • Under “Transport Settings”, copy the Calculated Access URL
  • Final endpoint:
    https://<host>:<port>/<calculated_access_url>
    Example: 
    https://ldciemt.wdf.sap.corp:44322/sap/bc/srt/xip/sap/businesspartnersuitebulkreplic/405/mdibpconsumer11/binding8

This URL is then used to configure the BPOUTBOUND destination in your BTP subaccount.

Conclusion

With this setup complete, your S/4HANA system is now capable of replicating Business Partner master data to SAP MDI in real-time via push or pull mechanisms. You’ve established secure communication, configured service groups, and integrated SOAP endpoints — ensuring a robust and scalable MDI architecture.
Please note the Blog is to connect S/4HANA on-prem/Private Cloud system to MDI, there can be more scenario where the MDI would be then connected to other systems. For such scenarios, configuration is required in Master Data Orchestration or Business Data Orchestration.

More Blogs:
SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): Architecture, D... - SAP Community
SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) – Bank and Cost ... - SAP Community

entry.title: Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters – A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration
entry.content:
In the era of APIs, hybrid landscapes, and cloud-native development, it's easy to assume that methodologies like SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology) are outdated. But the truth is: ISA-M is more relevant than ever. It remains a strategic compass for defining and implementing integration architectures that are sustainable, business-aligned, and tool-agnostic.

 

🔍 What is SAP ISA-M?

SAP ISA-M is a structured methodology that helps enterprises define their integration strategy, classify integration use cases, and select the right technologies and governance models. It supports decision-making across cloud, hybrid, and on-premise landscapes – regardless of whether you’re using SAP Integration Suite, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, or third-party platforms.

🔑 Why ISA-M Still Matters Today

  1. Strategic Guidance for Cloud Transformation

ISA-M is widely used during S/4HANA and RISE with SAP transformations to assess legacy middleware (e.g., PI/PO) and design modern, API- and event-driven target architectures.

  1. Technology-Agnostic by Design

ISA-M is not tied to specific products. It provides a framework for integration strategy, which remains valid even as tools evolve – from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite and beyond.

  1. Use Case-Driven Approach

By analyzing integration needs across five integration styles (e.g., process integration, data integration, event-driven integration), ISA-M helps teams design purposeful and scalable architectures.

  1. Connecting Business and IT

The methodology fosters collaboration between business owners, architects, and integration teams – ensuring that integration becomes a business enabler, not just a technical necessity.

 

Where ISA-M is Used Today

✅ Cloud Transformations & RISE with SAP

✅ Modernization of Legacy Interfaces

✅ Enablement & Governance Models

It outlines the phases in a modernization journey—Review, Scope and Define Use Cases—and shows how to transition towards a future-ready, hybrid integration platform.

  • Assess Integration Strategy
  • Review Existing Integration Architecture
  • Scope and Define Best Practices and Target Architecture
  • Give power to the people

 

🚀 Outlook: What’s Next for ISA-M?

🔧 1. ISA-M in INTAS – SAP Integration Assessment Service

SAP’s INTAS (Integration Assessment Service) is a structured offering to help customers evaluate and modernize their integration landscape. ISA-M provides the core methodology behind this service:

  • Assessment of legacy and custom interfaces
  • Mapping use cases to modern SAP Integration Suite capabilities
  • Tailored modernization roadmap aligned to Clean Core principles

With INTAS, organizations benefit from a guided modernization plan that is both strategic and executable.

I will give you some more insights in on of our upcoming Integration Modernization expert sessions: https://events.sap.com/expertsession-isam/en_us/home.html

🔗 2. ISA-M and the SAP Integrated Toolchain

The SAP Integrated Toolchain for Modernization Projects combines multiple SAP tools and services, such as:

  • SAP Cloud ALM
  • SAP Signavio
  • SAP LeanIX
  • SAP WalkMe
  • SAP BTP ( with our focus on Integration Suite)

We us ISA-M acts as a strategic layer below the toolchain, ensuring that all activities – from modeling to implementation – follow a consistent integration strategy. For example:

  • LeanIX is the central tool for your overall Enterprise Architecture  → ISA-M will help to control technologies and applications along the concept and to establish a government model
  • Signavio is used to model business processes → ISA-M helps derive integration patterns
  • SAP Integration Suite itself can be used to integrate the toolchain (itself) → ISA-M ensures style and governance fit, e.g. usage of SAP Advanced Event Mesh in combination with LeanIX Webhooks.

ISA-M connects the dots, providing strategic continuity across the entire toolchain.

We are currently working out an Integration Modernization expert which will give the required insights how you can implement it. Stay tune and follow our journey here https://events.sap.com/eur-sap-integration-modernization-expert-sessions/en_us/home.html

You would like to practice (e.g. with Integration content)? Just let me know.

🧼  3. ISA-M and Clean Core

Clean Core is one of the key guiding principles in SAP’s modernization strategy. But a Clean Core isn’t just about avoiding modifications – it’s about separating business logic from system logic and creating modular, scalable architectures.

Here’s how ISA-M supports a Clean Core approach:

  • Recommends using APIs, events, and standardized integration styles
  • Avoids hard-coded dependencies between systems
  • Encourages centralized governance and reuse of services

By following ISA-M, companies are not just modernizing their interfaces – they are actively cleaning their core.

 We hosted a first session how ISA-M can help you to ensure a clean-core approach Find the recording here: https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/e/video/embed/vAemLss?ltr=a&rc=10&doi=SAP1206809&includeSapBrandedWraper=true&includeRelatedAssets=true

 

✅ Final Thoughts

Integration is no longer just a technical challenge – it’s a strategic business discipline. And while the tools and technologies evolve, the need for a methodical, business-aligned integration strategy remains constant.

That’s why ISA-M continues to be a critical success factor for integration modernization, clean core transformation, and cloud-centric architectures.

Whether you're just starting your transformation journey or reviewing an existing landscape, ISA-M gives you the structure, language, and clarity to do it right.

👉 Explore more:

  • ISA-M GitHub Repository
  • ISA-M Mission in SAP Discovery Center

 You need support? Send us a mail SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) – Bank and Cost Center Replication from S/4HANA
entry.content:
In continuation of my previous blogs on MDI Architecture and Deployment and Business Partner Replication, this post focuses on Bank and Cost Center replication from an SAP S/4HANA system to SAP Master Data Integration (MDI).

Master Data objects like Banks and Cost Centers are foundational across multiple systems. Enabling seamless replication to MDI ensures a harmonized master data landscape, supporting a clean core and extensible architecture.

Common Configuration Steps

Before configuring the replication-specific models, there are common prerequisites applicable to both Bank and Cost Center integration. These ensure secured, authenticated communication and connectivity between S/4HANA and MDI.

1. OAuth 2.0 Client Configuration

Use transaction OA2C_CONFIG to configure your OAuth 2.0 client. This allows S/4HANA to authenticate securely with the SAP MDI service.

2. Create RFC Destination

Use transaction SM59 to create a destination pointing to MDI, essential for connectivity.

3. Configure MDI Destination

Use transaction S_SAL_71000052 to access view V_MDI_DEST_CONF and configure your destination here.

4. BGRFC Configuration

Set up Inbound BGRFC Destinations using SBGRFCCONF. This ensures reliable communication for asynchronous data transfers.

5. Extract AIF Content

Run /AIF/CONTENT_EXTRACT with SAP_COM_0659 to extract the content needed for integration scenarios.

6. Publish OData V4 Services

Use /IWFND/V4_ADMIN to publish OData V4 service groups if not already done.

7. Create Technical User

Use SU01 to create a user that will be used for background processing and secure calls.

8. Assign Required Role

Clone the role SAP_CA_DRF_MDO using PFCG and assign it to the technical user created above.

9. Configure SAP BTP Destination

Ensure the destination is correctly set in the SAP BTP Cockpit pointing to your S/4HANA On-Prem system.

Cost Center Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Configure a push model to automatically send data to MDI when a Cost Center is created or changed.

B. Pull Model Testing

To validate the integration, use a REST client such as Postman to pull data from MDI after the Push model replicates it.

Sample replicated Cost Center data can be verified in Postman once changes are triggered from S/4HANA.

C. Output Test

Bank Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Similar to Cost Center, set up a Push Model for Banks to send data changes automatically to MDI.

B. Pull Model Testing

Again, Postman can be used as a mock target system to verify the successful pull of replicated bank data from MDI.

C. Output Test

Summary

With this setup, you’ve now enabled real-time or near-real-time replication of Bank and Cost Center data from S/4HANA to SAP MDI, supporting both Push and Pull models. This ensures data consistency across systems and promotes a modular, scalable enterprise data architecture.

Please note the Blog is to connect S/4HANA on-prem/Private Cloud system to MDI, there can be more scenario where the MDI would be then connected to other systems. For such scenarios, configuration is required in Master Data Orchestration or Business Data Orchestration.

More Blogs:
SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): Architecture, D... - SAP Community
SAP MDI: SAP S/4HANA Business Partner Replication using DRF Customizing - SAP Community

entry.title: Optimized IDoc Routing in SAP CI with Value Mapping and Groovy-Based Receiver Determination
entry.content:
Target Audience

This blog is primarily intended for the SAP Integration community seeking a strategy for routing outbound IDoc flows from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems—particularly for those migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration (Formerly known as SAP Cloud Platform Integration or SAP CPI) and exploring effective alternatives to implement the same.

Motivation

In traditional SAP PI/PO-based landscapes, routing outbound IDocs from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems is straightforward. A single t-RFC destination and IDoc port are typically configured in the sender system to forward all IDocs to SAP PI. Within SAP PI, routing is managed efficiently using the Integration Directory and centralized runtime (AEX), enabling reuse of a single IDoc destination across multiple interfaces and message types (MATMAS, INVOIC, DEBMAS, etc).

However, when migrating to SAP Cloud Integration, this simplicity is disrupted. Cloud Integration does not provide an equivalent mechanism for managing IDoc traffic using a central gateway or common destination. Instead, each interface often requires its own unique endpoint, destination, and port, making the configuration effort redundant and makes IDoc Routing complex  and operationally challenging, as part of this blog I wanted to tackle these challenges and simplify this. (* I wont go into the specific challenges of the different approches and rather focus on the problems I am trying to solve in the current approach)

 

Solution Approach:

As described in the flow above, we will implement the design using two iFlows:

  • IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting:
    This iFlow receives IDoc XML messages from various SAP systems. It is responsible for receiver determination and routes the message to the appropriate target iFlow based on routing logic.
    In SAP PI/PO terminology, this iFlow handles the Inbound Processing and Receiver Determination steps of the integration pipeline.

  • IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>:
    This iFlow is specific to the receiver system and handles transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.
    In SAP PI/PO terms, this iFlow corresponds to the Interface Determination and Outbound Processing steps of the integration pipeline.

IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting

Step 1: Extract Details from EDI_DC40 of IDoc xml and create Exchange properties: 

The IDoc routing in this flow primarily relies on Value Mappings and Groovy scripts. In this step, the necessary inputs and variables are initialized—these are later used in Groovy script execution to extract routing details from the configured Value Mappings.

For example, consider a sender system Q10 (the quality environment of the x10 SAP system with client number 001) sending an INVOIC IDoc with an extension type ZINVOIC01. The properties are initialized as below.

                                    

The sentReceiverCount variable is initialized to zero and is later used during processing when the same IDoc meets conditions for multiple receivers, ensuring it is sent to each applicable receiver accordingly.

Step 2: Fetch Receiver List for the IDOC from the Value Mapping tables using Exchange properties:

For this we would need to maintain two value mappings

Value Mapping for Sender Partner Number to Sender Identifier Conversion:

As an example, I have maintained the details of SAP systems x10 and x20 across their Development, Quality, and Production environments. You would similarly maintain all relevant SAP systems and their corresponding identifiers in the Value Mapping used for IDoc routing. This mapping typically requires updates only when new SAP systems are added or existing systems are migrated (when SIDs change), which are relatively infrequent events.

Value Mapping for ReceiverList, Receiver Determination and Receiver Target IFlow URls:

The second Value Mapping is maintained for each unique combination of SAP sender system and IDoc type.
For example, to define receiver determination conditions for the IDOC: INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 sent from the SAP system x10, you would create a corresponding Value Mapping entry as shown below.

The ValueMapping will have 3 Mapping with agency as x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 (sender Identifier.IDOC)

IDOCName to ReceiverList : This mapping holds a list of all receivers applicable for a specific IDoc.

ReceiverName to ReceiverCondition: This defines the receiver determination condition for each receiver. The conditions should be maintained using XPath expressions to evaluate the IDoc content dynamically.

ReceiverName to ReceiverIFlowAddress: This maps each receiver to the endpoint URL of its corresponding integration flow (IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>) , as described earlier in the solution approach.

Now that we've covered how the Value Mappings are maintained, let’s look at how the Groovy script fetches the appropriate values:

1. Fetch senderIdentifier
The senderIdentifier is retrieved using the exchange property senderPartnerNumber (set in step 1). This value is looked up from the first ValueMapping.
Example:
If a message is sent from system Q10 with sender partner number Q10_001, the senderIdentifier fetched from the Value Mapping would be x10.

2. Construct Agency Key
Using the senderIdentifier and other exchange properties (set in step 1), the agency key is constructed. This key will be used to retrieve routing information from the second ValueMapping.
Agency Format:
<senderIdentifier>.<messageType>.<IDocType>[.<extensionType>]
     senderIdentifier – from first Value Mapping
     messageType – from exchange property
     IDocType – from exchange property
     extensionType – from exchange property (optional)
Example:
For an INVOIC IDoc of type INVOIC01 with extension ZINVOIC01 sent from system x10, the agency would be: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01

3. Fetch Receiver List
Using the constructed agency key, the receiver list is retrieved from the second ValueMapping.
Example:
For the agency x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01, the receiver list will be:
Receiver1, Receiver2, Receiver3
Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverList')

Step3: Execute Receiver Determination Conditions (Groovy Script) from Value Mapping

The Groovy script then iterates through the receiver list, fetching the corresponding receiver determination condition for each receiver and evaluating it against the IDoc content using XPath.

// Fetch condition from Value Mapping
currentReceiverCondition = valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverName',
  'Receiver1',
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverCondition'
)
// Evaluate condition
def expr = xpath.compile(currentReceiverCondition as String)
def result = expr.evaluate(doc, XPathConstants.BOOLEAN)

If the condition evaluates to true, the receiver is added to the exchange property determinedReceivers. A counter variable determinedReceiverCount is also maintained to track how many receivers matched successfully.

At the end of this step, three additional exchange properties will be available: determinedReceivers, determinedReceiverCount, and IDOCName (which holds the constructed agency key).

In the example discussed, lets consider if the conditions are satisfied for Receiver2 and Receiver3, then the determinedReceivers list will contain both, and the determinedReceiverCount will be set to 2.
The IDOCName property (i.e., the agency key: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01) is also stored to be reused in subsequent steps of the flow.

Step 4: Send Message to Receiver Specific flow for the  Determined Receivers 

In this step, a looping process call is executed, which repeatedly invokes a local integration process to send the message to each receiver identified in the previous step—one at a time.

The property sentReceiverCount is incremented after each message is successfully sent to a determined receiver. The loop continues until sentReceiverCount equals determinedReceiverCount, at which point the process terminates.

To send the message to a specific receiver, a Groovy script is used to retrieve the receiver name from the determinedReceivers list. Using this name, the script fetches the endpoint URL of the corresponding receiver-specific iFlow from the second ValueMapping.

Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverIFlowAddress'
)

The fetched endpoint URL is then assigned to the header property receiverProcessDirectURL, which is used by the ProcessDirect adapter to route the message to the appropriate receiver-specific iFlow. IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description> which would handle  transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.

 

Advantages of the Proposed IDoc Routing Strategy in SAP Cloud Integration

 The strategy outlined in this blog offers a scalable, modular, and maintainable alternative that aligns closely with enterprise integration requirements. Below are the key advantages of this design:

1. Reusability of Integration Flows

Instead of creating a separate iFlow for each IDoc-to-receiver combination, this approach separates:
Generic routing logic (IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting)
Receiver-specific logic(IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface>)
Benefit: Reduces development effort and avoids duplication across iFlows, enabling a clean and modular architecture.

2. Centralized Routing with Value Mappings

Routing conditions and receiver lists are managed through Value Mapping artifacts.
Benefit: Updates to routing logic can be done without modifying or redeploying iFlows—just update the Value Mapping configuration.

3. Scalable Across Systems and IDoc Variants

Routing logic is built dynamically using:
- Sender system identifier
- Message type
- IDoc type
- (Optional) Extension type
Benefit: Supports complex multi-system, multi-IDoc scenarios without inflating the number of artifacts or flows.

4. Native Support for Multi-Receiver Scenarios

The use of Groovy logic and looping constructs enables routing to multiple receivers based on evaluated XPath conditions.
Benefit: Enables 1:n routing scenarios, ensuring the same IDoc can be routed to multiple receivers without message duplication logic.

5. Low Maintenance and High Adaptability

This architecture requires Value Mapping updates only when:
- New SAP systems are added
- Existing systems are migrated
- Additional receiver conditions are introduced
Benefit: Minimal maintenance effort over time; no need for frequent design or deployment changes.

6. Aligned with SAP PI/PO Routing Model

The flow structure mirrors familiar SAP PI/PO pipeline steps, such as:
- Receiver Determination
- Interface Determination
- Outbound Processing
Benefit: Simplifies migration for teams transitioning from SAP PI/PO to SAP CI, while preserving key routing concepts. Also there is a scope for automation where you could write a code to automate creation of Valuemapping. The existing  ports can be reused by updating the RFC destination pointing to the SAP CI 

This approach attempts to addresses the Technical limitations of SAP CI’s IDoc handling, and also supports sustainable growth and cleaner and maintainable integration landscapes.

Additional Considerations for Retry and Reprocessing

  1. Retry and error handling should be implemented within each receiver-specific flow to manage failures independently for every receiver.

  2. It is advisable to avoid broadcasting IDocs directly from SAP Cloud Integration, especially in high-volume scenarios like master data distribution across multiple systems. This is due to potential limitations in storing failed messages within the SAP Cloud Integration tenant. Additionally, in broadcast cases, the retry mechanism should support resending only to the receivers where failures occurred, not all recipients.

  3. Exceptions can be returned to the sender system (e.g., via SOAP fault) so that errors are reflected in the originating SAP system(Return Exception to Sender ). This enables visibility in transaction logs like WE02/WE05, helping to identify and reprocess failed IDocs more effectively.

  4. Batch jobs in the SAP backend responsible for reprocessing IDocs should be adjusted based on the new failure status codes introduces by this setup

 

Conclusion

This blog attempted to present a scalable, maintainable, modular and  operationally efficient strategy for receiver determination of outbound IDocs from SAP system by leveraging Groovy script and Value Mapping. Also by decoupling the routing and receiver-specific logic into two separate iFlows, the solution ensures better reusability, easier maintenance, and greater control over message processing.

entry.title: Clean Core by Design: Using SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) as the First Principle
entry.content:
In the digital era of today where digital transformation is every organization’s need, SAP Clean Core Principle is more than just a word, it's a among the foundational principle for enterprises looking to future-proof their SAP landscape. As per the SAP clean core approach, where technology is moving towards API first Approach, modular architectures, the organizations must decouple their custom logic instead of the application server to external API’s outside the application server layer to ensure agility, scalability, and reducing the upgrade complexity.

One of the most powerful enablers of this Clean Core approach is the event driven architecture through SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), an enterprise-grade event brokering solution that supports real-time, event-driven architectures across hybrid landscapes.

In this blog, I’ll walk you through how to achieve Clean Core by adopting AEM as the first principle, laying the groundwork for a decoupled, scalable, and intelligent enterprise.

 The Clean Core Strategy — What and Why?

  1. Avoid Extensions where not required
  2. Upgrades should not interfere with the extensions and extensions should not interfere with the upgrades
  3. Decouple the extensions from the Standard
  4. Keep the custom code separate from the S4 Core

A Clean Code

The Clean Core strategy focuses on:

  • Keeping custom code, extensions, and integrations outside the SAP S/4HANA digital core.
  • Leveraging side-by-side extensibility using SAP BTP.
  • Using stable APIs and events to communicate between systems and layers.

This approach ensures that your core ERP remains clean, lean, and easily upgradeable—an essential factor for reducing TCO and accelerating innovation cycles.

In short, minimize extensions, decouple them from the standard, build side-by-side extensions on the BTP layer without touching the S4 HANA Core.

 Why AEM as the First Principle?

To achieve the clean core strategy, event driven architecture plays an important role by decoupling the processes through individual events, following the loosely couple framework and avoiding tightly coupled integrations.

SAP Advanced Event Mesh enables event-driven architecture (EDA) that decouples the source of truth (S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, C4C, etc.) from consumers (external apps, extensions, APIs). Here's why it's foundational to Clean Core:

  • Asynchronous Communication: No tight coupling between systems.
  • Loose Integration: Replace point-to-point interfaces with publish-subscribe models.
  • Extensibility: Let consumers build side-by-side extensions without modifying the core.
  • Scalability: Support multiple consumers with minimal configuration overhead.

 Clean Core in Action — Event-Driven Architecture with AEM

Let’s take a simple example: BP Onboarding in SAP S/4.

 Without Clean Core (Tightly Coupled):

  1. Custom ABAP enhancements in S/4HANA to trigger BP Creation/ Change Events.
  2. Direct API calls or IDoc triggers to downstream applications like ARIBA/ C4C/ Hybris/ External Applications from S/4.
  3. Every new consumer or change = new code or regression testing.

 With Clean Core (Using AEM):

  1. S/4 HANA triggers the BP Creation Event via Event Enablement Cockpit.
  2. AEM captures the events and routes it to all the subscribers.
  3. Subscribers (CPI, CAP apps, external systems) performs the required logic without modifying the core system.

No enhancement. No code in the core. Just events and clean extensions.

Common Use Cases Where AEM Drives Clean Core

  • Customer/Vendor Create in S/4HANA → Event to AEM → Update CRM/External apps.
  • Purchase Order Created → Event routed via AEM → Notify suppliers via external systems.
  • Material Master Update → Trigger downstream analytics apps or warehouse systems.

 Building Blocks of a Clean Core Event Strategy

1. Enable Eventing in Source System

    • Use Event Enablement Cockpit in S/4HANA (Cloud or Private Edition).

Within the SAP Application layer, where various types of event triggers are captured, these triggers can originate from the standard SAP mechanisms/ processes like Business Objects Repository(BOR) Event, Change Documents (CDHDR/ CDPOS), BTE(Business Transaction Event), IDOC Creation, Output Determination routines, and RAP based Event Triggers.

     

2. Route Event to AEM

    • Configure the required events in SAP S/4 to Publish Events to SAP Event Mesh/ AEM
    • Do the proper topic configurations and ensure secure connectivity.

3. Integrate with AEM

    • Use AMQP 1.0 protocol or SAP Event Mesh/ Advance Event Mesh Adapter in Integration Suite.

  1. Design Reusable Consumers
    • Keep business logic in SAP BTP (CAP, CPI, etc.).
    • Use topic naming standards (e.g., sap/s4/customer/created).

  2. Govern Events
    • Maintain versioning, documentation, and routing rules in AEM.


       

 Combine AEM with SAP Integration Suite or APIM

AEM becomes even more powerful when used alongside SAP Integration Suite:

  • Route events from AEM to CPI flows for orchestrations or APIM for Just Routing.
  • Use Process Integration for sync calls only where truly needed.

Practical Use Case:

Connect the S/4 or ERP to Advance Event Mesh (Either via Enterprise Event Enablement or ASAPIO Add-on) and setup the corresponding business events and topic hierarchies in AEM,

Go to the Broker Manager of the of the AEM,

Setup the Event Configuration via SAP Enterprise Event Enablement in the S/4

1. Create Queue

 

2. Subscribe to the Topic

 

 

3. Advance Event Mesh Subscriber Configuration:


4. Depending on the Design, Processing Configuration Can be Altered


or



or



 

Summary

In SAP S/4 HANA, achieving Clean Core is no longer an optional choice, it’s a foundational strategy for designing scalable, maintainable, and future ready enterprise landscapes. This blogs explored how the SAP AEM empowers the organizations to adopt event driven architecture(EDA) that supports the Clean Core Principle by:

  • Decoupling the Core: Separating the custom logic, integrations, and extensions from the S/4HANA core using publish-subscribe event models.
  • Enabling Side-by-Side Extensibility: Leveraging SAP BTP and AEM to develop external applications and microservices without modifying the digital core.
  • Ensuring Upgrade Agility: Keeping the S/4 core untouched allows smooth upgrades with minimal regression testing.
  • Scaling Across Hybrid Landscapes: Distributing business events asynchronously to multiple consumers (on-premises and cloud) with minimal configuration overhead.

 Conclusion

Embracing SAP Advanced Event Mesh as the foundation of your integration and extension strategy ensures that you're not only building for the present, but also for the future. With AEM, you unlock a Clean Core architecture that is:

✅Upgradable
✅Extensible
✅Decoupled
✅Scalable

The Clean Core is no longer a destination, it’s a design principle. And AEM is your first step on that journey.
