entry.title: SAP RISE - Six Integration Patterns You’ll Face
entry.content:
In one of my previous blogs Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters – A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration I have given some insights in which projects & situations I am currently using ISA-M to define my Integration patterns.  What should be more strategic then RISE nowadays?  

 

🧭 The Integration Architect’s Dilemma in RISE Projects

It usually starts with excitement — “We’re moving to RISE!”. But as the Integration Architect, you feel a shift in the room once you ask:

“How will your business-critical integrations survive the move?”

“How will our Integration Patterns change in a Private Cloud Environment?”

“Do we have to an option to be part of this modernization?”

In too many RISE conversations, integration is not part of initial phases , but everything depends on it. Whether you’re facing direct system-to-system integrations, legacy SAP PO platforms, or the modernization path toward Integration Suite and AEM: you need clarity.

 

Let’s talk about the 6 most common integration scenarios I encounter in RISE projects — and let’s do a deep dive into one of them.

📌Context: What Makes RISE Integration Different?

ISA-M allows us to talk in Integration patterns — proven, repeatable ways to connect cloud, on-prem, and hybrid landscapes.

Draw your Integration landscape abstract as below and repeat the same for all Integration Domains and Integration Patterns, maybe Integration Styles. We focus on the common Process Integration patterns which often are.

🔍 Scenario 1: On-Premise to On-Premise (e.g., existing ECC system → S/4, within same on-prem datacenter)

💬 Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their systems locally. No RISE adaption in this case

🔍 Scenario 2: Private Cloud to Private Cloud (e.g., S/4 to S/4 Integration, within same RISE datacenter)

 

🔧Technology in use:

  • SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on a Private Cloud hyperscaler, such as Azure or AWS 
  • VPN or direct peering within same hyperscaler
  • Azure VNet Peering, AWS VPC Peering, or similar as secure tunnel
  • *SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on On-Premise landscape ( e.g. on SUSE or Red Hat) is also a valid option

Differentiators

  • Usage of Application Interface Framework for S/4HANA Monitoring
  • Usage of transactions and APIM Management operations
  • Usage of SAP CALM for overall central Monitoring ( if applicable)

🔍 Scenario 3: Private Cloud to Public Cloud (RISE workload connects to SaaS like SuccessFactors)

💬 Comment:

For hybrid Integration SAP Integration Suite could be used as natural entry point

🔍 Scenario 4: Public Cloud to Public Cloud (e.g., SuccessFactors ↔ Ariba or Salesforce ↔ S/4 in RISE)

💬 Comment:
This is a modernization sweet spot. Cloud-native to cloud-native with no concrete RISE touchpoints.

🔍 Scenario 5: On-Premise to Public Cloud

💬 Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their backend systems locally but use SaaS applications for certain LoBs. No RISE adaption in this case

🔍 Scenario 6: On-Premise to Private Cloud (e.g., ECC → RISE in Azure, hybrid operation)

💬 Comment:
This hybrid pattern is very common in staged RISE transitions. Customers keep some systems on-prem while moving others (“early adaptors) into RISE.

 

🔧Modernization Reality Check

Most customers do one of three things:

  1. Move PO Interfaces to SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration  and SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell  
  2. Modernize to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  3. Use more featreus of the SAP Integration Suite, such as API Managmenet

So here’s what I recommend to every architect:

  • Audit your interface and integration technologies before RISE.
  • Classify interfaces using along the patterns in this blog.
  • Decide per pattern: Keep, Modernize, or Sunset.
  • Actively design your new integration landscape — don’t wait for someone else to.

 

📞 Let’s Build Smarter RISE Integrations

I’ve worked on numerous RISE integration journeys and built a reference architecture library covering each scenario. If you want to see the diagrams, dig into patterns, or compare your setup — I’m happy to help.

Ping us on SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: Let's demystify Event vs. Data Streaming in EDA
entry.content:
Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) is becoming increasingly more-an-more mainstream choice for the Integration Architecture approach. EDA seems to be a right choice for the modern Enterprises, aiming toward Composable Business and its agility. EDA can provide “Decoupled Integration” which is the essence of the Compossible Business way of thinking (as already elaborated, in my previous article)[1].

EDA should be considered as a key capability and thus included in any Enterprise Architecture transformation and modernization initiative. Of course, it’s not only EDA, but EDA is the core enabler for the Composable Business Architecture, because EDA supports:

  • Scalability
  • Flexibility
  • Resilience
  • Data quality

Figure 1. EDA and its role EA

EDA is what?

An Event-Driven Architecture is an integration model built to publish, capture, process, and respond to events across distributed systems in (near) real time[2]. It uses events to trigger and communicate between decoupled services and it is common in modern applications, which are built with microservices[3].

Because of its nature (i.e. PUSH data), EDA is very often referred to Event Streaming or Data Streaming. In specific cases, we may also refer to IoT Streaming. While this small “mess” in the semantic and terminology is confusing, we are in fact always talking about the same – we are talking about an Event Broker which is providing Event Choreography for all connected client system – no matter if they are Source System(s) or Target System(s).

But what are we really talking about? Are we really providing Streaming of the Events or Data?

What is an Event?

In general terms, an Event is a thing that happens or takes place, usually with a particular importance. But it is just too broad definition. In the context of IT or OT, and EDA, we will consider that Event is any detectable occurrence or (significant) change in a system's state that can trigger a certain action. It is also discrete and immutable record of the change. In respect of EDA, we see that Event is basically a trigger for some Data (whether IT or IoT or IIoT etc.) to be pushed or published from the Source System toward Target System, which is subscribed to receive it. We are not really “sending” an Event, we are always sending some Notification (or Data in general). Event is just a trigger.

If we talk about Business Systems, like SAP S/4HANA or similar, Event would be creation of the new Sales Order or change of the Sales Order line items or so. This change is a trigger for some action – what action we are triggering this is different story…

  • We may send an Event Notification that new Sales Order line idem has been added, or some existing has been changed – usually in a form a very short message, in SAP S/4HANA with so called CloudEvent. Sending a Notification is sometime designated as Event Streaming. Ordinarily, client system(s) may invoke a RESTful request to pull additional data from the source.
  • We may send Data Notification for the new Sales Order – usually replicating full Data Record. Sending full Data Record is sometime also called Data Streaming, especially if we are replicating data from ERP System to i.e. some Analytical System or Data Lake (although this is in fact not a continuous stream of Data, but transmission of distinct Data Records based on the Business Event trigger). Ordinarily, we do not expect any response from the client system(s)
  • We may also send something in between, like Decision Notification where i.e. certain items in the Sales Order are not available (after ATP B check) but also sending a proposal of the replacement items – usually this is small message payload carrying only minimum necessary data for the client system to make a “decision”. Here we do expect client system to make a “decision” and usually invoke some further processing in the ERP System.

SAP S/4HANA system supports many standard OOTB (Out-Of-The-Box) CloudEvents, and those are mostly Event Notifications[4].

Figure 2. Example of the Event Notifications

What is Data?

Generally accepted definition could be that Data is a collection of facts, figures, symbols, or descriptions that represent something, often used for analysis, reasoning, or decision-making. We are often referring to Data as something “row”; while we observe an Information as something which was produced out of the "raw-data" – something which has Business “meaning”. From the perspective of EDA, in Business Systems like SAP S/4HANA or similar, Data is a Record or a Document (or a part of it) – i.e. Sales Order, or Business Partner, or Accounting Document etc.

What is Streaming?

In the context of IT or OT, by pure “unofficial” definition, Streaming is a continuous flow of Data from a Source System to a Target System, often processed in real-time as it arrives.

  • In the domain of IT, as indicated previously, Business Systems like SAP S/4HANA or similar, will not provide (usually) continuous flow of Data, but rather distinct messages containing specific i.e. Data Records or Documents. Even if we have huge number of messages, they would still be distinct messages being published as a result of some specific Business Event(s). Despite this, we are still (very often) using terms like Event Streaming or Data Streaming.
  • However, in the domain of OT (or IoT/IIoT), many machines or devices, can produce both (depending on the particular use-case): distinct Data based on specific Technical Events (i.e. monitoring alert or so); as well as continuous flow of Data (i.e. telemetry). In both cases we tend to call it IoT Streaming (or Edge Integration), although first use-case is more like “standard” Event Notification.

When we talk about IoT Streaming, we usually talk about large or very large number of small messages being sent by the Source System (or Device), i.e. based on different sensor reading or so.

Figure 3. Example of the Telemetry Stream

Main integration models of EDA – or just terminology “mess”?

Is Event Notification the same as Event Streaming, and is this the same as Data Streaming?

Yes and no – depends of the terminology one uses. Many companies and experts will continue using different terminologies – although, thinking of the exactly the same thing. Somehow, I tend to agree with the terminology associated mostly with SAP Advanced Event Mesh (i.e. Event Notifications, Data Notifications and Decision Notifications) supplemented with some IoT specific (i.e. IoT Notification/Command and IoT Streaming), where each of the "integration models" describes the actual integration scenario/use-case. However, as it usually happens, in daily communication we all tend to generalize (or simplify) too much – using Event/Data Streaming to describe all EDA "integration models" seams to be a move in this direction. 

To make things at least a bit easier, let me try to share “some” high level mapping, of terminology, often used in various SAP Advanced Event Mesh papers, to other (simplified) terminology, often used by Gartner and some other organizations (although Gartner has its own split of EDA integration models):

Terminology

Triggered by

Other terminology

Event Notification

Business Event

Event Streaming

Data Notification

Business Event

Event or Data Streaming

Decision Notification

Business Event

Event Streaming

IoT Notification.
IoT Command

Technical Event

Edge Integration or
IoT Streaming 

IoT Streaming

Sensor reading or similar

Edge Integration or
IoT Streaming 

Here, the word "trigger" is more indicative. Of course, we may have other types of triggers - i.e. building custom Event Notifications based on some other type of ERP events or even based on scheduled jobs.

Final note

If you have noticed some inconsistency in this article, then you are right!

Let me now explain. If we talk about stream or continuous flow of Data, to be absolutely correct, we may even say – hey, this is not “really” Event-Driven Architecture, as there is no Event triggering anything… Technically, this is correct! But EDA is about Event Broker – and modern Event Brokers are capable of handling huge volumes of messages per second (or less) so, whether we are talking of IT Business Data, or OT continuous flow of Data, we would Orchestrate it (or provide Choreography – to be more precise) using an Event Broker.

So, let us adopt – no matter whether we publish message payloads based on Events, or they are based on sensor reading; no matter if it is small, or large message; no matter if clients are Business Systems, or clients are IoT devices – if we are using an Event Broker, we will consider this to be EDA integration model.

Well, this is at least my view, and my (simplified) "understanding"... 

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo by César Abner Martínez Aguilar on Unsplash 

**) Telemetry data/graph using Microsoft Copilot AI.

***) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] SAP Blogs: Integration patterns for the Composable Business A... - SAP Community

[2] SAP: What is Event-Driven Architecture (EDA)? | SAP

[3] AWS: Event-Driven Architecture

[4] SAP: Events | Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite – Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediation Steps
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite - Cloud Integration version 6.69.**, comes with an enhancement on Generative AI (GenAI) feature - GenAI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediations Steps.  This feature is an extension to GenAI based Integration Flow Generation as described in https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166 . This feature will be available only in SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration Premium Editions, on specific regions/data centres. This blog or product document will be updated with the list of regions/data centres once the rollout of this feature/software completes. 

This feature is forecasted to rollout in mid-September 2025 (these are tentative timelines, subjected to change as per internal phased rollout plan).

Update: Information about region-wise availability of this feature can be found in SAP Knowledge Base Article https://me.sap.com/notes/0003656393 

Enabling GenAI Based Integration Flow Generation feature

As tenant administrator of your premium edition tenant, you need to enable this feature in Settings page of SAP Integration Suite. Compared to steps mentioned in the earlier blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166, there is an enhancement in the settings page and the GenAI settings have been moved to a dedicated sub-navigation item called Artificial Intelligence, screenshot of which has been provided below. To enable this feature, you need to agree to the relevant terms and conditions.

Below are the sample screenshots of the same

Note : Flow Step Recommendations is a AI (ML) related feature which was/is available in all editions of Integration Suite. It is a alway's ON feature and tenant administrator will not be able to switch it OFF.  For more information, checkout the blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-cloud-integration-flow-step-recommendations/ba-p/13474550 

 

 

Generating Integration Flows with Mediation Steps

Once this feature is switched ON by the tenant administrator, you - as integration developer persona - can use this feature to generate integration flows. 

Now, you click on Add -> Integration flow menu in your package view, you will be given option for generating the integration flow with assistance from AI or create integration flow manually. 

Below are the screenshots of generating integration flows using generative AI.

If you observe the above screenshot, the description contains information about the components of the integration flow along with systems. This is the extension compared to previous feature version, wherein the generative AI backend layer recognises the components - also known as mediations steps - and generates the integration flow accordingly. 

Once the description is complete, click on send button.

The feature extension now also provides a detailed AI Response on what it has identified as systems, components and actions - kind of a reasoning - with which it will proceed for the integration flow generation. Click on Generate button. Below is the sample output of the generated integration flow.

As you can observe above screenshot, the generated integration flow has the flow steps which matches the components/mediation steps information provided in the integration flow requirement description as user input, along with that, integration flow is auto  aligned/auto formatted. The generative AI backend layer has provided proper names to flow steps/mediation steps as per the description, unlike static names like content modifier 1, message mapping 1 , which you might have observed when you manually drag-and-drop the flow elements and rename them - saves your time a lot. 

It has also generated resources, i.e., message mapping file for the message mapping flow step.

Currently, the generative AI backend layer is only generating empty/default resources., e.g., the generated message mapping file doesn't contain source and target schema structure as shown in the below screenshot.

The relevant resources's content like message mapping with schemas, groovy scripts with custom logic shall be supported in next upcoming increments. 

Summary

SAP Integration Suite – Cloud Integration GenAI based integration flow generation with mediation steps feature will help you bootstrap and accelerate the integration development activity.

As mentioned in the summary section of previous blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166 , this feature extension enhances the generative AI offering with mediations steps. Having said that, all is not complete yet. We noticed accuracy issues sometimes/in some cases - as with LLMs - in our internal validation. Some of the observations are : missing accuracy in generated integration flow and its mediation steps names/sequence connections, missing discovered UCL system's configuration with outbound adapters (please check previous blog on UCL approach in GenAI based Integration flow generation) and flow steps, empty/default resources like message mapping, groovy scripts, missing auto alignment/auto formatting, missing semantic connections for control flows (e.g. router, multicast) of generated integration flow.

We continue working on fixing accuracy issues as we make future releases, but the current extension in GenAI based Integration Flow generation with mediation steps should surely increase the integration flow developer efficiency.

entry.title: Agentic AI – AI which finally makes sense?
entry.content:
“A computer can never be held accountable, therefore a computer must never make a management decision.” – IBM Training Manual, 1979[1][2]

So, where are we with AI now? Isn’t Agentic AI doing exactly what it isn’t supposed to do?

AI or ML or?

We are bombed with terms – small break! Let’s digest this grocery of terms…

  • Data Science[3] is a broad interdisciplinary scientific field using scientific methods to extract knowledge and insights from the massive data sets. It uses both; traditional data mining, data analysis and statistical methods; as well as ML techniques, to accomplish the given tasks.
  • AI (Artificial Intelligence) is the broadest concept, aiming to create machines that can "think" and perform human-like tasks.
  • ML (Machine Learning)[3] is a subset of AI where algorithms learn from data without explicit programming, enabling predictions and pattern recognition. It does need Data Science to be employed first to clean, prepare and analyze unstructured big data
  • Deep Learning[4] is a type of ML based on artificial neural networks impersonating human “thinking”.

Neither ML nor AI are something brand new. It is considered that earliest ML “program” was introduced in the early 1950s (by Arthur Samuel). Mid 1950s was the time when AI somehow emerged as well. However, only in 2000s ML/AI started being more popular – simply because machines could not cope with the complex ML/AI processing, before that time. The real break-through (sort-of) came only in 2012 with Deep-Learning. Everything else is now a “legend”…

Figure 1. Data Science as a discipline

Is this the correct relationship between ML and AI?

There are somewhat different views, but let’s stick with the one which is the most common; Deep Learning is a subset of ML, ML is subset of AI, and Data Science is here to “help” them all. Still let me just mention – some other interpretation would put “all” under umbrella of Dats Science, while some views say that AI is only “partially overlapping” with ML and Deep Learning. However, we will (at least in this article) stay with the relationships as presented in this diagram.

Generative AI

AI is great, but next big evolution happened with Generative AI (or GenAI)[5].

So, what is Generative AI? While AI is very broad field of computer science focused on enabling machines to perform human-like tasks, Generative AI is a specialized subset of AI (or Traditional AI, as often referred) that creates new, original content such as text, images, or music – impersonating human-like creativity.

When we talk about GenAI, sometimes we mixed it with LLM (Large Language Model) – but this is, of course, not correct. GenAI encompasses various forms of content generation, while LLM is a foundation model for NLP (Natural Language Processing) tasks – oriented to text understanding and generation only.

Both GenAI, in general, and LLM are in the essence based on Deep Learning models.

Figure 2. Generative AI

Whether we talk about text, or image or music creation, the flow is basically the same; there is a prompt (usually created by the user), invoking GenAI processing of the request to understand and generate appropriate content (i.e. text or answer on the specific inquiry), and finally there is a GenAI generated response returned to the requestor.

Agentic AI

And here we come to Agentic AI, next big hype – AI which makes sense? AI which can make actual decisions!

In general, it is scary – I admit. But at least, now we have a concept which can really, really be useful in the daily work. Do not take me wrong GenAI is also useful for quite a few things, but it was mostly limited to do some recommendations, suggestions etc.– it was more as an assistant helping us do the work, but we still had to make decisions and do the work by ourselves. But now with Agentic AI we actually have a tool which can make the decision and do the actual work. Yes, it is scary really – but it is a reality, as well…

Agentic AI[6][7] is an AI system, with enhanced autonomy, enabling it to independently set goals, make decision on it, plan actions accordingly, and finally execute necessary tasks, without human intervention. Unlike Traditional AI, or “only” Generative AI, Agentic AI Systems are capable to understand complex context, learn from the interactions, and adapt to changing conditions. Within its “core”, Agentic AI Systems integrate LLMs – to work together with other agents. Agents can be other ML models, but those could be also calls to external tools (i.e. like API calls, DB actions etc.). In the system, through AI Orchestration each agent is performing specific subset of tasks required to reach the overall goal.

Figure 3. Agentic AI System has “brain”, “memory” and “tools”

It is exactly because of “agents” working with LLM “brain”, this approach is demonstrating high autonomy in solving problems; from understanding the context, invoking the right agents to perform “micro” tasks; aggregating all results, measure the success rate in meeting the goal, make the decision and execute the actions.

Agentic AI is focused on decisions as opposed to creating the content, like GenAI. Agentic AI does not rely on human prompts and does not require human supervision. But Agentic AI and GenAI tools work together, each of them takes their own role. In fact, Agentic AI could not do what it does, if there are no GenAI capabilities – core of the Agentic AI System relies on GenAI to make actions on the initial prompts (or inputs invoking specific agents via AI Orchestration), evaluating responses received form the agents, and generating final human-like responses on the prompts (if such actions is needed).

Figure 4. An example of steps within Agentic AI System

In real terms, the process could look like this:

  1. Agentic AI System uses its brain (i.e. LLMs) to understand the context (i.e. understand that prompt is asking for the specific Sales Order status) and generate the content for the external tool agents (i.e. API call to the ERP system).
  2. Usually, Agentic AI System will also have memory to store past context – to be smarter with similar prompts in future.
  3. AI Orchestration will invoke tools which will perform specific tasks (i.e. read the Sales Order detail from the ERP system, read LMD delivery status, retrieve knowledge from RAG or simply engage other agent) and return the results to the brain.
  4. All responses will be aggregated (i.e. if we are invoking several tools).
  5. Agentic AI brain may evaluate the conditions (if met) or it may measure success rate toward set goals (if satisfaction level reached).
  6. At the end, Agentic AI brain may trigger some actions, including providing response to the requester –this time it will create the content (i.e. human-like response with the Sales Order status).

Another typical example would be autonomous vehicles (or self-driving cars), where car AI must understand the complex context of the surrounding driving conditions, take the necessary inputs, and act toward reaching the goal. In this process car AI will make autonomous driving decisions and steer the vehicle accordingly.

This is why Agentic AI is Ai which actual does make sense – as it actually can work for us… Of course, will it (eventually) work only for us – this is completely different topic – which I will try to address in the separate article.

Some more practical examples, addressing some additional topics about A2A, MCP including some SAP specific topics like Content Based Agents vs. Code Based Agents – I will also try to cover in the separate article.

And don’t worry. Agentic AI is current hype – but AI is evolving, there will more and more “hypes” in the future, I am quite certain…

Final Thoughts

So, Agentic AI makes decisions – and not only that, but they also execute actions! Let’s think about future and “real” self-driving cars!

Then, are we actually violating the principles set by IBM in 1979? I am not going to answer this question, but answer seems to be quite straight-forward, right?

Welcome to the future…

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo by Nahrizul Kadri on Unsplash

**) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use  governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] IBM: AI decision-making: Where do businesses draw the line? | IBM

[2] LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7271085510142439426/

[3] IBM: Data science vs. machine learning: What's the Difference? | IBM

[4] Wikipedia: Deep learning - Wikipedia

[5] Forbes: The Difference Between Generative AI And Traditional AI: An Easy Explanation For Anyone

[6] IBM: What Is Agentic AI? | IBM

[7] IBM: Agentic AI vs. Generative AI | IBM

entry.title: Part 2: Agentic AI – Governance, risks and dilemmas
entry.content:
Agentic AI is jet another evolution of Traditional AI, right? It brings more than Generative AI (GenAI), but is also carries out some more risks as well… It’s becoming “smart”, it’s making “decisions” – and IBM told us in 1979 we shouldn’t let computers make “decisions” because computers cannot be “accountable”[1]!

I’ve tried to explain the AI evolution path in my previous article (Agentic AI – AI which finally makes sense?). Now, let’s talk about governance, risks and ethical dilemmas.

We should be aware of it, and we should try to address it – in time…

Let’s start with dilemmas…

Agentic AI can make autonomous decisions and based on this it can execute some complex tasks – also autonomously. This can be useful, yes – for sure this is much more than just GenAI assistants, where we had to make the decision and execute task on our own. Now we can have real robotic personal assistants, or self-driving cars, or robotic support agents. Tomorrow (and this tomorrow can come very fast) we will have fully autonomous HR agents and procurement officers, as well as fully autonomous industrial and humanoid robots, and let’s say this loudly – war robots as well (oh, I am sure bunch of people are already working on it, as we speak).

Figure 1. Are we concerned?

Dilemma is clear – where does this lead us at the end? Are we, out of our curiosity (or need to simplify our lives?) producing something which can replace us, or worse?

I do not have an answer on this – future is unwritten chapter – we are writing it now.

Agentic AI is reality, and now we should find the best way to use it! But at the same time,  we must create our future in a smart and sustainable way – and I hope we will.

Now, risks…

As per risks with Agentic AI, like with any AI or GenAI, there are some “standard” risks, for sure. But here I see that primary risk, is the risk of misuse by design – and this I link with the above dilemmas… I am not referring only to wrong design (i.e. being bias), I am referring on more serious “intentional” use for the “wrong” cause. What kind of agents and robots do we want to build? How much autonomy do we really want to give to AI? Although there are many articles, there are effectively no binding principles and guidelines. We are still too much intrigued with Agentic AI (or AI in general) – so no boundaries are set.

But it should be! As long as we do not set reasonable (and sustainable) boundaries, we are at (major?) risk.

Figure 2. Key Risks leading to shortcomings

For the “standard” risks, we have all those any GenAI might have – starting with security vulnerabilities like prompt injection and data poisoning, to model hallucinations. With Agentic AI both can lead not just to “ill” recommendations, but to “bad” decisions and “wrong” actions taken.

Additional risk, also starting with GenAI – the more cognitive tasks we pass to AI, the less cognitive tasks we will execute – this may not be good, in the long run. Similar with Agentic AI – the more decisions and actions are done by AI, the more dependent we become – again, this is not good for us, in the long run.

Are we aware of these risks? Well, we should be…

Can we improve “things” with good Governance?

The key aspect of any governance is to, among others, minimize any shortcomings of the new tools, methods, projects etc. How can we do this for Agentic AI?

  • How do we ensure that Agentic AI System has been built in the transparent and explainable way – so we can easily understand its purpose and ability?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI is fair and responsible – that we do see it as non-bias in making decision?
  • How do we build-in accountability within Agentic AI System (even these are “computers”) – in a way humans can accept it (also avoiding misuse by design)?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI System is safe to operate of – prompt injection and data poisoning has been effectively prevented.

Many questions… But what are the key governing principles we must follow?

First and the most important – there are no strict or imposed principles and guidelines (at least not yet) what is that Agentic AI System (agent or robot) can and cannot do by design. So, if we talk about “formal” misuse of the technology – sorry there are none or close to none (at least formally) limitations. But “informally” yes – there are those “dilemmas” for potential misuse of the AI (by design).

While it looked like we were very far away from the “real” AI (it was just a hype, right?) we did not care too much about putting any “legislation”. However, now things do not look so distant... The closer we come to real technology break-through toward autonomous robotics – thighs are becoming more and more controversial.

So how to build AI, and especially Agentic AI (or some further evolutions) in a responsible manner?

Figure 3. Responsible AI is Human-centric

Let’s call this Responsible AI magic circle of “interaction”:

  • Agentic AI “imposes” certain Risks
  • Risks do “impact” us, Human
  • Human must “build” Governance rules and practices
  • Governance rules and practices are here to “control” Agentic AI

The fact currently there are no “legally” binding rules and principles, does not prevent us to set company or industry standards on our own – let’s call it AI best practice.

If we talk about rules, let’s start thinking – what is that we want to keep for ourselves? What is that we don’t want AI to do? How far are we from some futuristic scenarios and the need to build basic rules of robotics[2]? Maybe we should be ready to “move over” this mountain and embrace the fact “future is happening right now”!

For principles, things are a bit more straight-forward, and previous AI experiences can really help us:

  1. Risk management: identifying, assessing, and mitigating the unique risks posed by both GenAI and autonomous agents. We should try to address all risks; from compliance risks and what and why do we build (to be transparent and explainable, to be fair and responsible, and ensure maximum possible accountability), to security risks (to be safe to operate).
  2. Continuous monitoring and auditing: agents/robots need to be monitored continuously to detect any deviation from intended behavior, any ethical issues, or security breaches. Also, audit trails and logging of agent decisions are vital for accountability, where (ideally) no agents/robots should access, alter and remove any audit trails and logs.
  3. Organizational structure: creating a cross-functional AI governance boards and bodies to create policies but also monitor adaptation of these policies in all Ai initiatives, with special focus on agents/robots.

All this, and more if needed, can be easily translated into any organization dealing with Agentic AI. Each organization will make adaptations on its own, of course – but key is to be aware of risks and shortcomings, as well as all the potential benefits new Agentic AI technology is bringing. If we are aware, and we try addressing it with proper governance – it’s a good start…

So, can we start all this and be open-minded?

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo BoliviaInteligente on Unsplash

**) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use  governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] IBM: AI decision-making: Where do businesses draw the line? | IBM

[2] Isac Asimov: Three Laws of Robotics - Wikipedia

entry.title: SuccessFactors API using OAuth authentication method via SAP Offline SAML Assertion generator
entry.content:
Introduction

When integrating with SAP SuccessFactors, secure authentication is critical. Since HTTP Basic Authentication is deprecated, SAP recommends using OAuth 2.0 authentication for API access. A commonly used approach is the OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion flow, where a signed SAML assertion is exchanged for an OAuth access token.

For scenarios where interactive login is not possible (e.g., background jobs, middleware integrations), SAP provides an Offline SAML Assertion Generator. This tool enables the creation of signed SAML assertions offline, which can then be used to authenticate securely against SuccessFactors APIs.

1. Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure the following setup is in place:

  • API  User: A dedicated SuccessFactors API user exists

  • Certificates:

    Private key available to sign SAML assertions (used by the Offline Generator).

  • OAuth Client: Configured in SuccessFactors, with required API permissions.

Please see below the step by step guide to configure :

TASK 1 - Registering Your OAuth2 Client Application in Successfactors

  1. Create an Odata API user SF_ODATA_API in SuccessFactors with the required permissions:

 

  1. Registering Your OAuth2 Client Application in Successfactors:

 

 

 

By default, the company name will come here:

 

 

 

Now fill the required details:

  1. Application Name: You can use any name here but ideally you should prefer to give a name who will be using the Oauth for connect to the SuccessFactors so that it will be easy for any consultant to understand which Application is using Oauth for SuccessFactors.
  2. Description: Give some logical description about the set up or you can keep this blank as well.
  3. Application URL: You can pass any URL of the company requesting for the setup of Oauth . For example let’s say if my company  is XYZ trying to use this Oauth then you can put the URL as https://xyx.com , if CPI is using this Oauth then provide the CPI URL here https://XYX6Z.tmn.hci.eu1.hana.ondemand.com , if google is using this then give https://google.com.
  4. Bind to users: (Optional) You can enable this option to restrict the access of the application to specific users including business users and technical users. This is not required to check.
  5. User IDs: Ideally, we don’t bind with users so that anyone can access it. It is required if you enabled the Bind to User option (if point 4 is enabled), Enter the user IDs separated by comma who can only access the Oauth.
  6. X-509 Certificate: Click the button below to Generate X.509 certificate and it will open a window as shown below:

Click below button:

 

It will open a window as shown below:

 

 

  1. If you see closely only one field is mandatory here i.e. the common Name (CN) and here, you can put the Odata API username which you have created in the first step i.e. SF_ODATA_API.

 

 

  1. Please fill the username in the Common Name (CN) field and click on generate: After you click on Generate the below window will open. Download and copy the certificate and keep it in your local folder.

 

 

 

  1. Click on Register so that API key will be generated: Once you click Register then it will take you to the below screen:

 

 

 

 

 

  1. Click on View to see the API key:

 

 

  1. So, the registration is successful in Successfactors and till this step we have the below details with us: Keep all the information in your local drive so that you can find it quickly.

 

  1. Odata API user: SF_ODATA_API
  2. X-509 Certificate: Please note you can use the certificate from the downloaded file in the step no 8 when you open the downloaded file you can see two things inside the file one is the private key encrypted and other one is Begin of certificate and end of certificate. Please note we must choose the Private key encrypted file for the SAML generation later using command prompt in this document.

 

 

 

  1. API Key:

 

                  You can also edit, disable, and delete an OAuth2 client registration.

TASK 2 - Generating a SAML Assertion

Generate a Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) assertion for requesting an OAuth    token. I am going to explain how you can generate the SAML Assertion locally.

  1. Downloading the Maven file

You can download the maven file using the below link, this will help us to generate the SAML assertion which we will be using for the Oauth call using the postman: https://maven.apache.org/download.cgi

 

Download the below Zip file:

Binary zip archive     apache-maven-3.9.6-bin.zip

 

 

Click the link above and download the zip file in your local PC: The file will look like as shown below.

 

 

Unzip the file and keep in the below folder in C drive.

 

 

 

  1. Install the JDK latest version, you can easily get the free version if you search in google.

Choose the one which is required for your operating system. When you download and install, it will create the file in C drive as shown below:

  

 

 

  1. Use the command prompt and pass CD\ to go to the root directory i.e. C drive.  

     

Press Enter and you will use the below steps to confirm that maven and JDK installed :

  1. CD\: To go to main directory
  2. echo %JAVA_HOME%: To check the Java Home
  3. java -version to check whether jdk installed properly with which version.      

              

 

  1. cd C:\apache-maven-3.9.6\bin: It will reach the directory C:\apache-maven-3.9.6\bin
  2. Use mvn -v to check the Maven Apache version as seen below.

 

  1. Now we are confirming that Maven and JDK latest version are installed in the system.
  2. Change the system environment variables by searching the settings in the start button of your PC.

 

  1. Click on the environment Variables and below window will open:

 

Click on New and add the below details both in User variables as well as the System Variables, give the variable name as PATH and variable value as the location of the maven file, in my case it is stored in C drive. Similarly, give variable name as JAVA_HOME and give the variable value as the location of the JDK file as given below Please follow the below and add in both new user variable as well as in the system variable:

Variable Name: PATH

Variable value: C:\apache-maven-3.9.6\bin

Variable Name: JAVA_HOME

Variable value: C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-21

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Click Ok and you can see both the path and press ok to proceed. You can see now both the path has been updated.

 

 

  1.    Go to the attachment of the KBA , 3031657 - How to generate SAML assertion using SAP-provided offline tool - SuccessFactors - SAP for Me and download it and keep in C-drive.

 

Unzip the file and keep it in the c: drive as shown below:

 

Open the folder and open SAMLAssertion.properties as shown below:

 

When you will open SAMLAssertion.properties file you will find some dummy entries inside it, and we need to clean it and use the details which we have in TASK-1.

 

 

 

After cleaning the dummy value, the screen should visible as shown below:

 

Now we need to fill the details:

  1. token URL: https://<SF API URL>/oauth/token for example it should be something like https://api12preview.sapsf.eu/oauth/token.
  2. ClientID: API Key which you received while registering the client in Successfactors in our case the ClientID is  

     

      . You can refer above in TASK-1 step no 10.
  3. userName:The username(Odata API user we have used in CN name i.e. SF_ODATA_API)
  4. privateKey : The certificate we have copied from the manage Oauth from SuccessFactors at Task-1 step no 10.
  5. expireInMinutes=100000 ( Maximum possible value is 5258880)
  6. Save everything as mentioned above in a file and then run the script as mentioned below.
  7. Command -   cd C:\SAMLAssertionGen-master

 

 

  1. Press enter to go to the directory C:\SAMLAssertionGen-master

 

  1. Execute the below command now.

mvn compile exec:java -Dexec.args="SAMLAssertion.properties”

 

Press Enter:

It will start generation the saml assertion and you can see the here how it started but the actual saml assertion which we need to call the API in successfactors using Oauth we will be finding it at the end of the saml generation.

 

 

Assertion:

 

 

Once completed, it would generate SAML assertion. Copy this and store it securely in your local drive.

 

TASK-3 Calling ODATA API from Successfactors using Postman.

 

Now we have all the details with us, for example:

  1. SuccessFactors company ID
  2. SF API Key (from Manage Oauth)
  3. SAML Assertion

We must do two steps to query the data from the success factors Oauth.

  1. First Step: In this step, we will be calling the SuccessFactors to get the Oauth token. Please see the screenshot:

 

 

company_ID: Successfactors instance company id

client_id: API Key from the SuccessFactors Manage Oauth2 (Refer Task-1)

grant_type: urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:saml2-bearer

Assertion: SAML assertion generated in Task-2 (Refer to the last steps)

 

Now we have the token, we can move to step-2 to query the data from the SuccessFactors.

  1. Second Step: In this step we will be using the token generated in the above step and query the data from the SuccessFactors. Please see below screenshot.

 

 

You have put the query to get the data and select Authorization as Bearer token. In the Token field pass the token we got in the Step 1 and query the data. The query will be successful, and you will be getting the data.

 

 

You can export the collection from the postman and can share with the third party so that they can directly use this to set up to query the data using Oauth from SuccessFactors.

entry.title: IDOCs are Still Safe for SAP S/4HANA - SAP Clean Core Extensibility Level B
entry.content:
Intro 

IDOCs are safe to use in SAP S/4HANA programs—and if anyone tells you otherwise, point them to this blog to learn more. IDOCs are now officially part of SAP Clean Core Extensibility! That’s the big news from updated SAP Guidelines (OSS Note 3578329 – Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility).

This ends the myth that IDOCs are “dead.” They are not. They’re preserved as SAP Clean Core Level B Extensibility, which means your existing IDOC investments are safe. Let’s explore four perspectives—integration, monitoring and error handling, performance, and testing—to see where APIs are recommended first, and where IDOCs still bring value.

1. Integration Perspective

SAP’s recommendation for new development in S/4HANA is clear: use modern integration technologies such as APIs, events, or OData services. They are the strategic direction and best fit for greenfield or transformation projects. That said, not all projects require reinvention. If your business processes remain largely the same as in ECC, and the goal is to reduce cost and risk, IDOCs can still be used. They are not prohibited, and as long as an IDOC type is not listed as deprecated in the SAP Simplification List, it is safe:
https://help.sap.com/docs/btc/lean-sdt-best-practices/sap-s-4hana-simplification-analysis?locale=en-US Because IDOCs are now Clean Core Level B Extensibility, continuing with them is fully supported in SAP S/4HANA on-premise and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. They offer a pragmatic path to de-risk projects and leverage existing know-how. 

2. Monitoring and Error Handling Perspective

For new interfaces, SAP recommends using AIF (Application Interface Framework) to handle monitoring, error management, and business validations. AIF provides a powerful, unified monitoring layer, and in many cases it comes license-free (for standard SAP interfaces delivered in namespaces like /SDSLS or /LEEDI, or in CFIN, Document Compliance, or S/4HANA Public Cloud). Where APIs are deployed, AIF bridges the gap between technical payloads and business-friendly monitoring.

IDOCs still have a strong card here: their monitoring capabilities are mature, well-known, and integrated into standard SAP transactions. Functional users know how to work with WE02, BD87, and standard reprocessing flows. This means less training, less overhead, and faster resolution in day-to-day operations.

In other words: AIF is recommended, but IDOCs deliver proven stability in monitoring and error handling.

3. Performance Perspective

APIs are the recommended way forward, but they come with a structural tradeoff: their payloads are larger and typically handle transactions individually. This makes them more verbose and sometimes less efficient for high-volume use cases. IDOCs, in contrast, have long supported bundling, batching, and parallel processing at scale. They’ve been the backbone of high-volume EDI and SAP-to-SAP integrations for decades, and their ability to handle millions of documents daily is field-proven. So while APIs are the strategic choice for new designs, IDOCs remain a safe performance option for scenarios with heavy data throughput.

4. Testing Perspective

Testing support for APIs exists (for example, with SXI_MONITOR), but it is more technical and often requires additional training for functional teams. For IDOCs, simulation and reprocessing are familiar to almost every SAP functional consultant. Tools like WE19 and BD87 make IDOC testing and troubleshooting accessible, reducing dependency on specialist skills.

For projects that need to standardize and automate testing across both APIs and IDOCs, solutions like Int4 Suite provide simulation and test automation capabilities that unify all SAP integration scenarios. You can learn more on how to test and simulate SAP integrations in this SAP learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization So while APIs are recommended for new developments, IDOCs still offer ease of testing and proven tooling, especially in brownfield projects.

Conclusion

The strategic path forward in SAP S/4HANA is built on APIs, events, and frameworks like AIF. That’s the official recommendation, and it should guide greenfield and transformation projects. But IDOCs are far from obsolete. They are officially part of Clean Core extensibility, safe to use in both on-premise and private cloud, and carry unique advantages in performance, monitoring, and ease of testing. That makes them not only supported, but still a pragmatic and safe choice when the situation calls for stability, cost reduction, and risk mitigation.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here’s the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: “learn a test framework and run automated scripts,” we can say: “here are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.”

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a “Black Friday” scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure – run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure – fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn’t care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn’t about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It’s about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It’s the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

More information: 

Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
Int4 Suite — your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite
Agentic Testing and Simulation with Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph
